**G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28**.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, **David Ramirez**, and respectfully files this Complaint for Modification pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, **G.L. c. 209C, § 20**, and relevant Massachusetts caselaw, seeking modification of the existing custody judgment entered by this Court on **June 15, 2021**, in order to protect the best interests and welfare of the minor children, **Emily Ramirez (age 10)** and **Noah Ramirez (age 8)**.

**G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20**.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, **David Ramirez**, and respectfully files this Complaint for Modification pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, **G.L. c. 209C, § 20**, and relevant Massachusetts caselaw, seeking modification of the existing custody judgment entered by this Court on **June 15, 2021**, in order to protect the best interests and welfare of the minor children, **Emily Ramirez (age 10)** and **Noah Ramirez (age 8)**.

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: Under **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, a custody or visitation order may be modified upon a showing of a **material and substantial change in circumstances** and when modification is necessary to serve the **best interests of the child**.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody, visitation, and removal, but it does so in the context of an initial divorce judgment, not a modification proceeding under G.L. c. 208, § 28. The court interprets § 30 (removal) and § 31 (joint custody), and nowhere articulates the "material and substantial change in circumstances" standard or links it to § 28. Thus, this case is not authority for the specific modification standard stated in the proposition.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not, if of suitable age to signify his consent, be removed out of this commonwealth without such consent, or, if under that age, without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child…”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Under **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, a custody or visitation order may be modified upon a showing of a **material and substantial change in circumstances** and when modification is necessary to serve the **best interests of the child**.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on removal under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not modification standards under G.L. c. 208, § 28. While it mentions the American Law Institute Principles that describe relocation as a substantial change in circumstances, the court does not articulate or apply the § 28 standard that a custody or visitation order may be modified upon a material and substantial change in circumstances and where modification is necessary to serve the child’s best interests. Thus, it does not provide direct authority for the claimed § 28 proposition.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part: ‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances . . . only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce] … (4) When a relocation constituting changed circumstances . . . renders it impractical to maintain the same proportion of custodial responsibility to each parent, the court should modify the parenting plan in accordance with the child’s best interests….’”}

*Adoption of Ilona*, 459 Mass. 53 (2011).proposition: The Massachusetts appellate courts have repeatedly held that a **child’s safety and well-being supersede parental preferences.**
*Adoption of Ilona*, 459 Mass. 53 (2011).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in termination proceedings, parents’ rights are secondary to the child’s best interests and that the focus must be on the child’s welfare, even where the agency may have fallen short in providing services. The court emphasizes that a child’s interest in freedom from neglect or abuse is “absolute” and that the judge must still rule in the child’s best interests notwithstanding failures in reasonable efforts, which squarely supports the principle that the child’s safety and well-being supersede parental preferences or interests.
*Adoption of Ilona*, 459 Mass. 53 (2011).relevant_excerpt: “However, even where the department has failed to meet this obligation, a trial judge must still rule in the child’s best interest. ‘A determination by the court that reasonable efforts were not made shall not preclude the court from making any appropriate order conducive to the child’s best interest.’ … While courts protect the rights of parents, ‘the parents’ rights are secondary to the child’s best interests and … the proper focus of termination proceedings is the welfare of the child.’ … (‘While parents have a constitutionally recognized interest in maintaining the family unit, a “child’s interest in freedom from neglect or abuse is absolute”’).

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The Massachusetts appellate courts have repeatedly held that a **child’s safety and well-being supersede parental preferences.**
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion thoroughly reaffirms that the governing standard in custody cases is the child’s best interests and that the child’s welfare is the “paramount” concern, rooted in a tradition rejecting parental property-like claims. That framework necessarily places the child’s safety, stability, and well-being above either parent’s preferences or asserted rights, and the court applies that standard to structure custody despite the father’s competing wishes and arguments about his prior role.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… This legal principle replaced the notion that children were the property of their parents, and instructed courts to view children as individuals with interests independent of their parents… [T]he ‘best interests of the child’ standard… has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation… [T]he ‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern.’”

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: Exposure to domestic violence, instability, or the presence of individuals with violent histories constitutes a **substantial change in circumstances** warranting judicial intervention.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: The opinion is a custody dispute and remand focused on the need for explicit findings about the impact of domestic violence on the child and on the appropriateness of a custody award in light of that violence. It does not analyze or apply the “substantial change in circumstances” standard, nor does it frame exposure to domestic violence or instability as a change in circumstances warranting modification or other judicial intervention. The case instead concerns the proper initial/ongoing custody determination and the required factual findings, so it does not provide authority for the specific substantial-change proposition stated.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt: “We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below ‘fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.’ … The Probate Court failed to consider the special risks to the child in awarding custody to a father who had committed acts of violence against the mother. … Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

*Custody of Michel*, 28 Mass. App. Ct. 2.proposition: Exposure to domestic violence, instability, or the presence of individuals with violent histories constitutes a **substantial change in circumstances** warranting judicial intervention.
*Custody of Michel*, 28 Mass. App. Ct. 2.support_reasoning: The case concerns an initial care-and-protection adjudication and findings of parental unfitness, not a later modification based on a “substantial change in circumstances.” The court upholds temporary removal based on existing chronic domestic violence, parental psychological disorders, and chaotic home conditions, and states that a judge “does not have to wait for disaster to happen.” It does not analyze or apply any ‘substantial change in circumstances’ standard for modifying an existing custody order, so it cannot be cited as authority for that specific proposition, even though it recognizes domestic violence and instability as grounds for state intervention.
*Custody of Michel*, 28 Mass. App. Ct. 2.relevant_excerpt: “Temporary removal of a child from biological parents does not require that the child have suffered maltreatment… A judge sitting on this sort of case does not have to wait for disaster to happen. In determining parental fitness a judge may use past conduct to predict future ability and performance.”

*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.proposition: The “material change” threshold is satisfied when circumstances arise that could **adversely affect a child’s emotional or physical well-being**.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the standard for modifying alimony and child support in terms of a “material change of circumstances,” but it frames that standard around the parents’ financial circumstances, earning capacity, assets, needs, and related equities. It does not articulate or apply a rule that the material-change threshold is satisfied when circumstances arise that could adversely affect a child’s emotional or physical well-being. The case is about the payor’s financial changes, not about changes impacting a child’s emotional or physical health as a trigger for modification.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. … In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances. … The needs of the children, the financial status of the support provider, and the station in life of the respective parties must all be considered.”

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The parent seeking modification bears the burden to demonstrate the change and show that modification is in the children’s best interests.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly applies G.L. c. 208, § 28 and states that a judgment modifying custody “must be based” on findings that there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances and that modification is necessary in the child’s best interests—placing that burden on the party seeking modification (here, the father). The court repeatedly faults the probate judge for changing custody without sufficient findings of such a change, confirming that the moving parent must demonstrate both the change and that modification serves the child’s best interests.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28 (‘the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”

*Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610 (.proposition: The Commonwealth’s policy is clear: custody and parenting time must occur in a manner that ensures **a safe, stable, and nurturing environment.**
*Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610 (.support_reasoning: The case explicitly states that in custody proceedings “the rights of the children to a stable and safe environment” are at least as important as the parents’ interests, and it also emphasizes the Commonwealth’s interest in a “stable, continuous family environment.” While the opinion does not use the full phrase “safe, stable, and nurturing environment,” its reasoning clearly grounds Commonwealth child‑custody policy in ensuring stability and safety for children, which substantially supports (though does not verbatim state) the cited proposition. The ‘nurturing’ element is implicit rather than expressly articulated.
*Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610 (.relevant_excerpt:
“In custody proceedings, the rights of the children to a stable and safe environment assume an importance at least equal to the interest of the parents in a fair proceeding…
…[T]he delay by the parents in prosecuting this appeal is inexcusable given the significant interest in the speedy resolution of custody matters. See … (interest of children best served by a stable, continuous family environment).”

*Doe v. Doe*, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 499 (198.proposition: The Commonwealth’s policy is clear: custody and parenting time must occur in a manner that ensures **a safe, stable, and nurturing environment.**
*Doe v. Doe*, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 499 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion applies the statutory “happiness and welfare of the children” / best-interests standard and discusses whether a parent’s lifestyle adversely affects the child’s health, but it does not articulate any broad Commonwealth ‘policy’ framed as requiring a “safe, stable, and nurturing environment.” The language of the decision is focused on equal parental rights, best interests, and lack of adverse impact from the mother’s lifestyle, not on defining a general custody principle in the terms used by the proposition. Thus, citing this case for that specific policy formulation overstates what it actually holds.
*Doe v. Doe*, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 499 (198.relevant_excerpt: “Custody of David must be determined in accordance with G. L. c. 208, § 31…which provides in pertinent part: ‘In making an order or judgment relating to the custody of children… the rights of the parents shall, in the absence of misconduct, be held to be equal, and the happiness and welfare of the children shall determine their custody or possession. When considering the happiness and welfare of the children, the court may consider whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health…’”

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: Courts have discretion to order **supervised parenting time** when a child’s safety or welfare may be compromised by a parent’s companion or household environment.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody, relocation, and parenting schedules but does not address supervised parenting time or supervision conditions tied to a parent’s companion or household environment. The parenting time awarded to Rose is described as regular visitation (weekends, summers, holidays, webcam sessions), with no indication that it is supervised or conditioned on concerns about companions or environment. Thus, this case does not provide authority for courts ordering supervised parenting time based on safety or welfare risks from a parent’s companion or home setting.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: The judge’s custody order gave Rose frequent contact with Jill, including parenting time one weekend per month in Massachusetts, five weeks in the summer, school vacations, holidays, Web camera sessions three evenings per week, and telephone calls once per week. As discussed, the judge found that Hunter already has Jill telephone Rose every night to say good night.

*M.C. v. T.K.*, 463 Mass. 226 (2012).proposition: Courts have discretion to order **supervised parenting time** when a child’s safety or welfare may be compromised by a parent’s companion or household environment.
*M.C. v. T.K.*, 463 Mass. 226 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion deals exclusively with child support, shared physical custody, and income calculations under the Massachusetts Child Support Guidelines. It does not discuss parenting time/visitation restrictions, supervision of parenting time, or safety concerns relating to a parent’s companion or household environment. There is no language granting or reviewing discretion to order supervised parenting time, so the case does not support the stated proposition.
